It's never been easier to jump higher, bolder, or more daring than Evel Knievel, who is best remembered as the world's most iconic extreme stuntman. Born on July 17, 1938, in Butte, Montana, Evel Knievel, whose real name is Robert Craig Knievel, took the world by storm through his death-defying jumps, rocketing motorcycle stunts, and larger-than-life personality.

From a young age, Knievel was fascinated with motorcycles and thrills. He first rode a bike at the tender age of 3 and by the age of 7, he was already racing at the family garage. He spent most of his teenage years in high school, but dropped out to pursue a career in professional motorcycle racing. His relentless passion and natural talent quickly earned him respect among his peers and soon enough, he became a popular figure on the racing circuit.

Knievel's big break came in 1967 when he was hired by actor George Hamilton to perform at a series of rodeo events. His daring stunts and charismatic persona won him a loyal following and soon he found himself performing in front of packed audiences at the Cannes Film Festival in 1968. This marked the beginning of his legendary career.

Knievel quickly rose to fame with his "Solo-Man" series of jumps, where he attempted to jump over 21 ramps across the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom. In 1972, his jump over the Snake River Canyon, which is now known as the "Jump Over The Snake River Canyon," gained worldwide attention and became the subject of countless news articles, TV segments, and books.

Knievel's daring jumps captured the imagination of millions and solidified him as a national celebrity. Despite experiencing many injuries throughout his career, Knievel continued to push the limits of what was possible. His final jump attempt, which was supposed to take place in 1999 at the Empire State Building, was tragically cut short when he crashed, leading to his untimely death on November 30, 2007.
